facts.text: On August 3, 1957, at 10.00 p.m., a motor car bearing No. WBC 562 was stopped by Excise Inspector R.R.P. Sinha (P.W.1) on Bayley Road near New Secretariat, Patna.
The car belonged to appellant's brother Radhey Shyam, who was not in the car. The car was driven by Jagdish Sah, appellant sitting by his side, four other persons on back seat.

Car searched in presence of Debendra Prasad Singh (P.W.2), Paresh Nath Prasad Singh (P.W.3), Rabindra Prasad Singh (P.W.4). Recovered five bundles of non-duty paid Nepali Ganja: four from luggage boot, one from leg space in front of front seat.
Appellant produced keys with which luggage boot opened. Seizure memo Ex.2 made. Statements recorded, including appellant's statement Ex.3.
Bunch of keys Ex.2 series from appellant's pocket, Ex.1 series from driver Jagdish Sah. Keys from both could open luggage boot lock.
Appellant arrested at 6.00 a.m. on August 4, 1957 at house of Kanhai Singh (D.W.1) in Subjibagh Mohalla, Patna.
All persons in car including appellant and Radhey Shyam tried before Judicial Magistrate First Class, Patna, who convicted all.
Sessions Judge, Patna acquitted all except appellant in appeal.
Patna High Court affirmed appellant's conviction under s.47(a) Excise Act, sentence of 1 year RI and Rs.2000 fine, in Criminal Revision No.1274 of 1960 dated January 20, 1961.
Seizure memo Ex.F (Ex.2?) shows material alterations and erasures: originally bundle of 35 seers in leg space front rear seat overwritten, weights adjusted, appellant's name inserted over erasures.
Appellant's defence: Not travelling in car, falsely implicated, signature taken on blank paper after threats, abuses, assault by Excise officers.
All courts accepted prosecution evidence that appellant was in car when stopped.

legal_issues.text: Whether a confession made by the appellant and recorded by the Excise Inspector investigating the case is inadmissible by reason of s.25 of the Indian Evidence Act, 1872.
Whether the Excise Inspector is a 'police officer' within the meaning of s.25 Evidence Act given powers under Bihar and Orissa Excise Act, 1915.
Whether the confessional statement is also inadmissible under s.162 CrPC as recorded during investigation.
Sufficiency of evidence excluding confession to sustain conviction under s.47(a) Bihar and Orissa Excise Act.

petitioner_arguments.text: Confessional statement Ex.3 inadmissible under s.25 Evidence Act as made to police officer.
Statement inadmissible under s.162 CrPC as recorded by Excise Inspector investigating excise offence.
Seizure memo Ex.F materially altered with erasures and overwritings, no reliance possible.
Evidence of PW2,3,4 and Inspector insufficient without confession; no exclusive possession by appellant as keys with driver also opened boot, 6 persons in car.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s.47(a) Bihar and Orissa Excise Act

respondent_arguments.text: Excise Officer not a police officer; confession admissible.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: s.25 Indian Evidence Act; State of Punjab v. Barkat Ram

court_reasoning.text: Excise Inspector under s.78(3) Bihar Excise Act deemed officer in charge of police station for s.156 CrPC wrt his area; exercises all powers of O/C police station under Ch.XIV CrPC for excise offences.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Powers facilitate obtaining confessions; test is whether powers tend to facilitate obtaining confession from suspect.

court_reasoning.text: Excise Officer position differs from Customs Officer (Barkat Ram): deemed O/C PS, full investigation powers under CrPC, not limited/judicial.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Logical to hold confession to such officer same as to police officer.

court_reasoning.text: Confession also inadmissible u/s 162 CrPC as statement during investigation by officer exercising powers of O/C PS.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Both s.25 Ev Act and s.162 CrPC exclude it.

court_reasoning.text: Without confession, direct evidence of PWs not sufficient; seizure memo unreliable due to alterations; no exclusive possession.
court_reasoning.key_observation: High Court ignored alterations in Ex.F; conviction cannot stand.

court_reasoning.text: Dissent (Dayal J.): Excise Officer not police officer; Act revenue-oriented, investigation powers incidental; s.78(3) limited to s.156 CrPC purpose.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Powers not make him police officer for s.25; distinguishes from regular police.

holdings.text: Excise Inspector empowered u/s 77(2),78 Bihar Excise Act is 'police officer' for s.25 Ev Act when investigating excise offence.
Confession to such officer inadmissible u/s 25 Ev Act and s.162 CrPC.
No legally admissible evidence to sustain conviction u/s 47(a) Excise Act without confession.

precedents_cited.case_name: State of Punjab v. Barkat Ram
precedents_cited.relevance: Customs officer not police officer u/s 25 Ev Act; powers limited, revenue focus; question of Excise officer left open.
Object of s.25 to prevent extortion of confessions by police through torture etc.
'Police officer' in wide popular sense, not strict technical.
Excise officers with full police powers under Abkari Act are police officers u/s 25.
Full Bench: Excise officer exercising CrPC powers is police officer u/s 25.
Excise officer not police officer; limited discussion, pre-amendment.

precedents_cited.case_name: Radha Kishun Marwari v. King Emperor
precedents_cited.relevance: Excise officer not police officer; construed narrowly, contra to Barkat Ram.

statutes_cited.name: Bihar and Orissa Excise Act, 1915
statutes_cited.relevance: Defines powers of Excise Officers; deems them O/C police station for investigation of excise offences.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Evidence Act, 1872
statutes_cited.relevance: No confession to police officer proved against accused.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Criminal Procedure, 1898
statutes_cited.relevance: Statements during investigation inadmissible except contradiction; powers of investigating officer.

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed, conviction under s.47(a) Excise Act and sentences of 1 year RI and Rs.2000 fine set aside as confessional statement inadmissible under s.25 Evidence Act and s.162 CrPC, no other sufficient evidence.

key_quotes.text: The test for determining whether such a person is a police officer for the purpose of s.25 of the Evidence Act would... be whether the powers are such as would tend to facilitate the obtaining by him of a confession from a suspect or a delinquent.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Key test adopted by majority for deeming Excise officer as police officer.

key_quotes.text: It would be logical, therefore, to hold that a confession recorded by him during an investigation into an excise offence cannot reasonably be regarded as anything different from a confession to a police officer.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: I do not consider the confession to be inadmissible in evidence as being made to a police officer. The Excise Inspector does not come within the expression 'police officer' in s.25.
key_quotes.speaker: court
